div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [Evening Star, Washington, D.C., June 25, 1925]
div1.opener:
BACKGROUND OF EVENTS
------------------------
BY PAUL V. COLLINS.
Oct 6/25
Evening Star.
Washington D. C
div1.p:
Dean Swift little thought that he
was speaking more truth than poetry
when he wrote:

lg.l: Hath smaller fleas that on him prey.
And these have smaller still to bite 'em.

div1.p:
That was written nearly two cen-
turies ago, but it waited until the
last decade for verification by men
of science.

Pasteur demonstrated more than
40 years ago the foundations of bac-
teriology, proving that ferments and
putrification did not produce new ani-
mal life, as was generally taught up
to that time, but that everywhere
there exisited bacteria, with great
functions in nature, producing
changes in matter, causing diseases,
but sometimes contributing invaluable
aid in food production. Pasteur's dis-
coveries set scientists at work along
entirely new lines of research, but
neither he nor his successors for 30
years after his demonstration knew
that the immeasurably small bac-
teria which play such a part in dis-
ease themselves have parasites like
“smaller fleas to bite 'em.”

One of the greatest achievements
in medical research since Pasteur's
day was accomplished by a Washing-
tonian, Dr. Henry Rose Carter, as-
sistant surgeon general of the United
States Public Health Service, who
died in this city a fortnight ago. In
the official review of Dr. Carter's
career, issued by the Public Health
Service, following his death, it is
stated:

“Among the most notable of his
sanitary and scientific achievements
may be mentioned: The determination
of the period of extrinsic incubation
of yellow fever, a foundation on which
the brilliant work of Walter Reed and
his commission rested, and for which
Dr. Carter was nominated for the
Nobel prize by the distinguished Eng-
lish physician and sanitarian, Maj.
Donald Ross. He was intimately as-
sociated with Gorgas and Reed
throughout the greater part of their
careers.”

Both Gen. Gorgas and Dr. Walter
Reed testified to the greatness of Dr.
Carter's work as a pioneer in finding
the secret of yellow fever, the mos-
quito, as the host carrying the fever
germs. Kitasato, the famous Japa-
nese scientist, says of Dr. Carter's
work: “It is the only advance in mari-
time quarantine since the time of the
Venetians.”

What wonders have really been
accomplished in sanitation and pro-
longation of human life in recent
years! The Carter achievement,
based on Pasteur's work, is one ex-
ample. Other research has combined
to raise the average life from 39.8
years, in 1855, to 55 years and 2
months in 1920. Science thus donates
16 years, on an average, to all humans
in civilized countries.

The United States Public Health
Service, as is pointed out by its chief,
Dr. Cummings, has eradicated small-
pox in the Philippine Islands, where
it had been epidemic for centuries;
has controlled cholera in the same
region, and completely annihilated it
in continental United States. It has
checked bubonic plague in California,
Texas, Louisiana and Florida. It has
helped demonstrate the transmission
of typhus fever by body parasites. It
has given the first demonstration that
beriberi was caused by eating polished
rice, deficient in certain vitamines.
It has shown that the plague was
kept alive by germs carried by ground
squirrels. It has developed a method
of treating oysters from polluted beds
so as to make them safe for food.
It has identified the American hook-
worm and, by the Carter research,
conquered yellow fever.

We no longer fear cholera or small-
pox, yet as late as 1873 there was a
serious cholera epidemic in the United
States, and it was a novel idea put
forth by Dr. Woodworth, supervising
surgeon of the Marine Hospital Serv-
ice, in his report to Congress, to the
effect that cholera came from “unor-
ganic poison gaining entrance through
the alimentary canal.”

In 1902 there were in the Philippines
166,252 cases of cholera with 109,461
deaths. In that year 4,000,000 died
of cholera in India. So thoroughly
has the disease been conquered that
while in 1911 many ships arrived bear-
ing cholera cases, only two cases re-
-------------------------------------
sulted in Brooklyn, one in New York
and two in Boston.

All these medical victories are attrib-
uted directly to bacteriology.

No less serious than cholera was
yellow fever. Prior to the Civil War
yellow fever was continuous in New
Orleans and other Southern cities,
so that it was assumed to be endemic
there. While the disease cannot be
traced back earlier than the seven-
teenth century, in 1793 it killed one-
tenth of the population of Philadel-
phia and one-twentieth of the people
of New Orleans. In 1905 an epidemic
of yellow fever in New Orleans killed
one-tenth of the patients. Then Dr.
Carter began his investigations, re-
sulting in proving that a mosquito
was the carrier of the germ, and the
wholesale killing of mosquitoes has
saved millions of human victims of
the scourge. Yellow fever is wiped
out.

Now comes a recent discovery that
mankind has an ally in the fight
against the bacteria germs of disease.
It is called “bacteriophage,” which
means, literally, that it is something
which “eats up bacteria,” a parasite
of bacteria which destroys them. This
was not known prior to 1917, and is
scarcely yet recognized even by ad-
vanced scientists as an important fac-
tor in future fighting of disease.

Entomologists have long recognized
that the best way to fight an insect
pest is to make use of the natural
enemies of the insect. Sanitarians
will, by research, discover possibilities
of fighting microbes by the “smaller
fleas to bite 'em.” Like Paul Jones,
they “have just begun to fight.”

The first publication regarding bac-
teriophages was in 1917, by Monsieur
F. d'Herelle of the Pasteur Institute,
Paris, and the first English transla-
tion of the book. “The Bacteriophage:
Its Role in Immunity,” was published
in 1922 by George H. Smith, Ph. D., of
Yale University.

To illustrate briefly the action of
bacteriophage, the test was made with
two specimens of water containing
“vibrio cholerae.” The first specimen,
filtered through porcelain, contained
2,500 organisms per cubic centimeter;
after three hours no organism re-
mained. The second specimen was fil-
tered and boiled. The boiling killed the
enemy of the bacteria--the bacterio-
phage--so that, starting with 5,000,
after three hours it contained 10,000;
after 40 hours, 36,000. The water of
the Jumna River in India, during the
last cholera epidemic, left the town
of Agra containing 100,000 germs per
cubic centimeter, but 5 kilometers
downstream it had so purified itself
by its bacteriophage that it contained
only 90 to 100 per cubic centimeter.

Until 1915 such cleansing was
thought to be due to “a volatile some-
thing in the water which disappeared
by boiling.” Now it is recognized to
be “ultramicrobes,” called bacterio-
phage, so infinitely small that not
even when dyed can they be seen
through any microscope, even though
microscopes can make visible the elec-
trons of an atom.

Just as bacteria are made more
virulent by scientific cultures, so a
new possibility may be found in de-
veloping the enemies of all microbes
by culture of bacteriophage until they
will be so powerful as to be able to an-
nihilate any germs. That opens a new
method of attack of disease without
drugs.

All animals (including humans) are
loaded with bacteria, at all times, but
each animal contains resistance pow-
ers against his own bacteria--subject
to being overpowered in cases of physi-
cal weakness. But one man's mi-
crobes, thus held harmless upon him,
may be virulent if transferred to an-
other person who is unimmunized
against it. Hence the danger of
coughing in the presence of other per-
sons, which might carry germs to
them. Russian Soviets are reported
recently to have forbidden all hand-
shaking and kissing because of the
danger of the practice.

A surgeon connected with the
United States Public Health Service
is authority for the statement that it
is more important to glove the hands
than it is to wear a mask in surgical
operations. With the mask the sur-
geon is obliged to touch it more or
less with his hands, each touch carry-
ing germs to the mask. With gloves
on the hands, handshaking is warned
off. He agrees with the Russians that
handshaking is dangerous.

It has long been argued that public
handshaking by the President, or by
other public men, should be abolished
from a sanitary standpoint. The same
is applicable to promiscuous hand-
shaking and kissing, at least unless
accompanied with a sufficient regi-
ment of active bacteriophages to at-
tack the germs, for every little germ
has a bacteriophage of its own.
